title: The Commitments (musical)
text:
The Commitments is a <a href="musical%20theatre">musical</a> written by <a href="Roddy%20Doyle">Roddy Doyle</a>, based on the <a href="The%20Commitments%20%28novel%29">1987 novel of the same name</a>, also written by Doyle. Like the novel (and <a href="The%20Commitments%20%28film%29">its 1991 film adaptation</a>), the musical is about a group of unemployed Irish youths who start a <a href="soul%20music">soul music</a> band. It premiered in 2013 at the <a href="Palace%20Theatre%2C%20London">Palace Theatre</a> in <a href="London">London</a>'s <a href="West%20End%20theatre">West End</a>.
The music within the musical consists of soul and <a href="rock%20%26amp%3B%20roll">rock & roll</a> classics from the 1950s and 60s, including "<a href="Think%20%28Aretha%20Franklin%20song%29">Think</a>", "<a href="%28I%20Can%27t%20Get%20No%29%20Satisfaction">(I Can't Get No) Satisfaction</a>", "<a href="Papa%20Was%20a%20Rollin%27%20Stone">Papa Was a Rollin' Stone</a>" and "<a href="Night%20Train%20%28composition%29%23James%20Brown%20version">Night Train</a>". The music is entirely <a href="diegetic%20music">diegetic</a>, meaning that all the songs are performed by the band rather than being sung by characters to express an emotion. For that reason, Doyle has insisted that "The Commitments" is not a <a href="jukebox%20musical">jukebox musical</a>.
Background.
The musical is based on the <a href="The%20Commitments%20%28novel%29">1987 novel</a>, by <a href="Roddy%20Doyle">Roddy Doyle</a>. Following the 1991 film adaptation, Doyle said he received 20 different offers to turn the novel into a musical. He turned them all down because he had become resentful of the success of "The Commitments", to the seeming exclusion of his other novels; and because he was not a fan of musical theatre, having never seen a musical. He eventually changed his mind due to his children, who were fans of the 1991 film, and who took him to see musicals, including a production of the film-turned-musical "<a href="The%20Producers%20%28musical%29">The Producers</a>", which he called "a revelation".
Officially confirmed on 19 April 2013, in <a href="Ireland">Ireland</a>, producers announced that the show would play the <a href="Palace%20Theatre%2C%20London">Palace Theatre</a>, with tickets going on sale everywhere on 23 April. Despite initially looking to hire another writer to write the book for the musical, Doyle ended up writing the show himself. The show will be directed by <a href="Jamie%20Lloyd%20%28director%29">Jamie Lloyd</a>, with choreography by Ann Yee, set design by Soutra Gilmour, sound design by Rory Madden and lightning by Jon Clark. Ticket prices for the show began at £10, with all preview tickets half price.
Production history.
West End (2013–2015).
"The Commitments" began previews on 21 September 2013, at the <a href="Palace%20Theatre%2C%20London">Palace Theatre</a>, <a href="London">London</a>, before holding its official opening night on 8 October. On 20 August 2013, casting was announced with Denis Grindel playing Jimmy Rabbitte, <a href="Killian%20Donnelly">Killian Donnelly</a> playing Deco, Ben Fox playing Joey Fagan, Sean Kearns as Jimmy Rabbitte's father and Sarah O’Connor, Stephanie McKeon and Jessica Cervi playing The Commitmentettes. A typical London performance ran 2hrs 25mins, including one interval of 15 mins. On 21 May 2015, it was announced that the show would close on 1 November 2015.
UK and Ireland tour (2016–2017).
Upon the show's closing notice in London it was announced that a tour would commence in 2016. The production officially opened at Dublin's <a href="Bord%20G%C3%A1is%20Energy%20Theatre">Bord Gáis Energy Theatre</a> in October 2016, and closed at the Bradford <a href="Alhambra%20Theatre">Alhambra Theatre</a> on May 13, 2017. It featured a number of cast members from the West End production, including original cast members Brian Gilligan as Deco and Andrew Linnie as Jimmy. <a href="Kevin%20Kennedy%20%28actor%29">Kevin Kennedy</a>, best known as Curly Watts from "<a href="Coronation%20Street">Coronation Street</a>", joined the cast as Jimmy's Da.
UK and Ireland tour (2021–2022).
It was announced that the show was to tour again from September 2020, however due to the ongoing <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a> the tour was postponed to open in September 2021 at the <a href="Birmingham%20Hippodrome">Birmingham Hippodrome</a>. Casting is yet to be announced.
Musical numbers.
The musical features nineteen main songs with a further nineteen short <a href="sound%20bite">sound bite</a>s of <a href="Soul%20music">soul</a> and motown numbers.
Critical reception.
The <a href="West%20End%20theatre">West End</a> production of "The Commitments" received mixed reviews from critics.
